sentences.sentence: “Son of Adam,” said Aslan, “you have sown( 播种 ) well.
And you, Narnians, let it be your first care to guard this Tree, for it is your Shield( 保护物 ).
The Witch( 女巫 ) of whom I told you has fled( 逃跑 ) far away into the North of the world;
she will live on there, growing stronger in dark Magic.
But while that Tree flourishes( 茁壮成长 ) she will never come down into Narnia.
She dare not come within a hundred miles of the Tree, for its smell,
which is joy and life and health to you, is death and horror( 恐惧 ) and despair( 绝望 ) to her.”

Everyone was staring solemnly( 严肃地 ) at the Tree when Aslan suddenly swung round his head( 猛地回头 ) (scattering( 散射 ) golden gleams( 微光 ) of light from his mane( 鬃毛 ) as he did so) and fixed his large eyes on( 注视着 ) the children.
“What is it, children?” he said, for he caught them in the very act of whispering and nudging( 用肘轻推 ) one another.
“Oh—Aslan, sir,” said Digory, turning red, “I forgot to tell you. The Witch( 女巫 ) has already eaten one of those apples, one of the same kind that Tree grew from.”
He hadn’t really said all he was thinking, but Polly at once said it for him. (Digory was always much more afraid than she of looking a fool.)
“So we thought, Aslan, that there must be some mistake, and she can’t really mind the smell of those apples.”
“Why do you think that, Daughter of Eve?” asked the Lion.
“Well, she ate one.”
“Child,” he replied, “that is why all the rest are now a horror( 恐惧 ) to her.
That is what happens to those who pluck( 摘下 ) and eat fruits at the wrong time and in the wrong way.
The fruit is good, but they loathe( 厌恶 ) it ever after.”
“Oh I see,” said Polly. “And I suppose because she took it in the wrong way it won’t work for her.
I mean it won’t make her always young and all that?”
“Alas( 唉 ),” said Aslan, shaking his head. “It will. Things always work according to( 根据 ) their nature.
She has won her heart’s desire; she has unwearying( 无尽的 ) strength and endless days like a goddess.
But length of days with an evil( 邪恶的 ) heart is only length of misery( 悲惨的生活 ) and already she begins to know it.
All get what they want; they do not always like it.”
“I—I nearly ate one myself, Aslan,” said Digory. “Would I—”
“You would, child,” said Aslan. “For the fruit always works—it must work—but it does not work happily for any who pluck( 摘下 ) it at their own will.
If any Narnian, unbidden( 未经要求的 ), had stolen an apple and planted it here to protect Narnia, it would have protected Narnia.
But it would have done so by making Narnia into another strong and cruel empire like Charn, not the kindly land I mean it to be.
And the Witch( 女巫 ) tempted( 诱惑 ) you to do another thing, my son, did she not?”
“Yes, Aslan. She wanted me to take an apple home to Mother.”
“Understand, then, that it would have healed( 治愈 ) her; but not to your joy or hers.
The day would have come when both you and she would have looked back and said it would have been better to die in that illness.”
And Digory could say nothing, for the tears choked( 使哽咽 ) him and he gave up all hopes of saving his Mother’s life;
but at the same time he knew that the Lion knew what would have happened,
and that there might be things more terrible even than losing someone you love by death.
But now Aslan was speaking again, almost in a whisper:
“That is what would have happened, child, with a stolen apple.
It is not what will happen now.
What I give you now will bring joy.
It will not, in your world, give endless life, but it will heal( 治愈 ).
Go. Pluck( 摘下 ) her an apple from the Tree.”
For a second Digory could hardly understand.
It was as if the whole world had turned inside out and upside down.
And then, like someone in a dream, he was walking across to the Tree,
and the King and Queen were cheering him and all the creatures were cheering too.
He plucked( 摘下 ) the apple and put it in his pocket. Then he came back to Aslan.
“Please,” he said, “may we go home now?” He had forgotten to say “Thank you,” but he meant it, and Aslan understood.
“You need no rings when I am with you,” said the voice of Aslan.
The children blinked( 眨眨眼 ) and looked about them.
They were once more in the Wood between the Worlds;
Uncle Andrew lay on the grass, still asleep;
Aslan stood beside them.
“Come,” said Aslan; “it is time that you went back.
But there are two things to see to first; a warning, and a command. Look here, children.”
They looked and saw a little hollow( 坑，洞 ) in the grass, with a grassy bottom, warm and dry.
“When you were last here,” said Aslan, “that hollow( 坑，洞 ) was a pool,
and when you jumped into it you came to the world where a dying sun shone over the ruins of Charn.
There is no pool now. That world is ended, as if it had never been. Let the race of Adam and Eve take warning.”
“Yes, Aslan,” said both the children. But Polly added, “But we’re not quite as bad as that world, are we, Aslan?”
“Not yet, Daughter of Eve,” he said. “Not yet. But you are growing more like it.
It is not certain that some wicked( 邪恶的 ) one of your race will not find out a secret as evil( 邪恶 ) as the Deplorable Word( 灭绝咒 ) and use it to destroy all living things.

And soon, very soon, before you are an old man and an old woman, great nations in your world will be ruled by tyrants( 暴君 ) who care no more for joy and justice and mercy( 仁慈 ) than the Empress( 女皇 ) Jadis.
Let your world beware( 当心 ). That is the warning. Now for the command.
As soon as you can, take from this Uncle of yours his magic rings and bury them so that no one can use them again.”
Both the children were looking up into the Lion’s face as he spoke these words.
And all at once (they never knew exactly how it happened) the face seemed to be a sea of tossing( 起伏不定的 ) gold in which they were floating,
and such a sweetness and power rolled about them and over them and entered them that they felt they had never really been happy or wise or good, or even alive and awake, before.
And the memory of that moment stayed with them always, so that as long as they both lived,
if ever they were sad or afraid or angry, the thought of all that golden goodness, and the feeling that it was still there, quite close, just round some corner or just behind some door,
would come back and make them sure, deep down inside, that all was well.
Next minute all three of them (Uncle Andrew now awake) came tumbling( 跌跌撞撞地 ) into the noise, heat, and hot smells of London.
They were on the pavement( 人行道 ) outside the Ketterleys’ front door,
and except that the Witch( 女巫 ), the Horse, and the Cabby( 马车夫 ) were gone, everything was exactly as they had left it.
There was the lamp-post( 灯柱 ), with one arm missing; there was the wreck( 残骸 ) of the hansom cab( 双轮有篷马车 ); and there was the crowd.

Everyone was still talking and people were kneeling( 跪着的 ) beside the damaged policeman, saying things like, “He’s coming round” or “How do you feel now, old chap( 伙计 )?” or “The Ambulance( 救护车 ) will be here in a jiffy( 一会儿 ).”
“Great Scott( 天哪 )!” thought Digory, “I believe the whole adventure’s taken no time at all.”
Most people were wildly looking round for Jadis and the horse.
No one took any notice of the children for no one had seen them go or noticed them coming back.
As for Uncle Andrew, what between the state of his clothes and the honey on his face, he could not have been recognized by anyone.

Fortunately the front door of the house was open and the housemaid( 女佣 ) was standing in the doorway( 门口 ) staring at the fun( 看热闹 ) (what a day that girl was having!) so the children had no difficulty in bustling( 催促 ) Uncle Andrew indoors before anyone asked any questions.
He raced up the stairs( 楼梯 ) before them and at first they were very afraid he was heading for his attic( 阁楼 ) and meant to hide his remaining magic rings.
But they needn’t have bothered( 担心 ).
What he was thinking about was the bottle in his wardrobe( 衣柜 ), and he disappeared at once into his bedroom and locked the door.
When he came out again (which was not for a long time) he was in his dressing-gown( 睡袍 ) and made straight for the bathroom.
“Can you get the other rings, Poll?” said Digory. “I want to go to Mother.”
“Right. See you later,” said Polly and clattered( 嗒嗒地跑 ) up the attic( 阁楼 ) stairs( 楼梯 ).
Then Digory took a minute to get his breath( 缓口气 ), and then went softly into his Mother’s room.
And there she lay, as he had seen her lie so many other times, propped( 靠着 ) up on the pillows( 枕头 ), with a thin, pale face that would make you cry to look at it.
Digory took the Apple of Life out of his pocket.

article_info.previous: Uncle Andrew被当做宠物关在笼子里，Aslan朝他吹了一口气让他睡着了。小矮人们为纳尼亚的国王和王后制作了两顶漂亮精致的王冠。加冕仪式完成后，大家发现Digory种下的苹果已经迅速长成了一棵枝繁叶茂的树。

article_info.share_words: And Digory could say nothing, for tears choked him and he gave up all hopes of saving his Mother’s life; but at the same time he knew that the Lion knew what would have happened, and that there might be things more terrible even than losing someone you love by death.

question.cn: 根据狮子的叙述，纳尼亚子民的首要任务是什么？
question.en: According to the Lion, what was the chief responsibility of Narnians?

options.en: To guard the King and Queen.

analysis: 文中提到“Narnians, let it be your first care to guard this Tree, for it is your Shield.”由此可知，纳尼亚的居民首要任务是保卫这棵树，因此选C。

question.en: Did the Witch eat the silvery apple?

analysis: 文中提到 “ I forgot to tell you. the Witch has already eaten one of those apples, one of the same kind that Tree grew from.”由此可知，女巫也吃了树上的银苹果，因此选A。

question.cn: 最后，Digory是否给妈妈带去了苹果？
question.en: At last, did Digory take an apple to his mother?

analysis: 文中提到“What I give you now will bring you joy. It will not, in your world, give endless life, but it will heal. Go. Pluck her an apple from the tree.”由此可知，Aslan在Digory走之前，允许他摘下一个树上的苹果带给他的妈妈，Digory照做了，因此选A。

question.cn: 在Digory和Polly回家之前，狮子给他们说了什么？
question.en: Before Digory and Polly went home, what did the Lion tell them?

analysis: 文中提到 “ But there are two things to see to first; a warning and a command. Look here, children.” 由此可知，在Digory和Polly回到现实世界之前，Aslan给他们说了两件事需要注意，一是警告，二是命令，因此选C。

question.cn: 根据Aslan的指示，Digory应该怎么处理魔戒？
question.en: According to Aslan, how should Digory deal with the magic rings?

options.cn: 他应该把魔戒丢在河里。
options.en: He should threw them into the river.

analysis: 文中提到“As soon as you can, take this Uncle of yours his magic rings and bury them so that no one can use them again.”由此可知，Aslan给他们的命令是埋掉魔戒，以防有人再次使用，因此选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第43天
